conclusion: The problem involves determining the maximum electromotive force (EMF) generated by the AC generator.
Figure (A) shows a schematic of a small rotating-armature AC generator with a rectangular coil connected to a resistor R via slip rings.
The magnetic flux through each turn of the coil varies sinusoidally with time, as depicted in the graph on the right.
The key parameters are: m = 100 turns for the coil, resistance r = 10Ω, external resistance R = 90Ω.
The EMF induced in the coil is given by EMF = dΦ/dt, where Φ is the magnetic flux through each turn of the coil.
The total resistance in the circuit is R_total = r + R = 10Ω + 90Ω = 100Ω.
The current I in the circuit is determined using Ohm's law: I = EMF/R_total.
The power dissipated in the circuit is P = I^2 × R_total = EMF × I.
Since the power dissipated is also equal to the rate of change of magnetic flux: P = dΦ/dt × I.
The maximum EMF can be found by solving the equation: EMF = √(2P/I).
Since the current I is small, the EMF is approximately equal to: EMF = √(2 × 100 × 10) = √2000 = 44.72 V.
The maximum value of the EMF is 44.72 V.
